### TimePoint {#a52f2c3fdd7f80c1991d8c7079489efff}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;typename D = std::chrono::nanoseconds&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>using llvm::sys::TimePoint =  std::chrono::time&#95;point&lt;std::chrono::system&#95;clock, D&gt;</>}>
A time point on the system clock.

This is provided for two reasons:
<ul>
<li>to insulate us against subtle differences in behavior to differences in system clock precision (which is implementation-defined and differs between platforms).</li>
<li>to shorten the type name The default precision is nanoseconds. If you need a specific precision specify it explicitly. If unsure, use the default. If you need a time point on a clock other than the system&#95;clock, use std::chrono directly.</li>
</ul>

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/chrono-h/#l00034">34</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/chrono-h">Chrono.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### CleanupOnSignal() {#ad01be72a9c0cb2dc4c676aa0057a9b31}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void llvm::sys::CleanupOnSignal (uintptr&#95;t Context)</>}>
This function does the following:

<ul>
<li>clean up any temporary files registered with <a href="#aee27cc5336ecd3f21eeda4ad2826b915">RemoveFileOnSignal()</a></li>
<li>dump the callstack from the exception context</li>
<li>call any relevant interrupt/signal handlers</li>
<li>create a core/mini dump of the exception context whenever possible Context is a system-specific failure context: it is the signal type on Unix; the ExceptionContext on Windows.</li>
</ul>

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/signals-h/#l00123">123</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/signals-h">Signals.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### ExecuteAndWait() {#abb13fbc7f52c659966b05092b19e6e19}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>int llvm::sys::ExecuteAndWait (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> Program, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> &gt; Args, std::optional&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> &gt; &gt; Env=std::nullopt, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; std::optional&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> &gt; &gt; Redirects=&#123;&#125;, unsigned SecondsToWait=0, unsigned MemoryLimit=0, std::string &#42; ErrMsg=nullptr, bool &#42; ExecutionFailed=nullptr, std::optional&lt; <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/sys/processstatistics">ProcessStatistics</a> &gt; &#42; ProcStat=nullptr, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/bitvector">BitVector</a> &#42; AffinityMask=nullptr)</>}>
This function executes the program using the arguments provided.

The invoked program will inherit the stdin, stdout, and stderr file descriptors, the environment and other configuration settings of the invoking program. This function waits for the program to finish, so should be avoided in library functions that aren&#39;t expected to block. Consider using <a href="#a76fe26a8f1401a60839398dedb2f170c">ExecuteNoWait()</a> instead. 
<SectionUser title="Returns">
an integer result code indicating the status of the program. A zero or positive value indicates the result code of the program. -1 indicates failure to execute -2 indicates a crash during execution or timeout
</SectionUser>

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/program-h/#l00104">104</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/program-h">Program.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/program-cpp/#l00032">32</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/program-cpp">Program.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### ExecuteNoWait() {#a76fe26a8f1401a60839398dedb2f170c}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>ProcessInfo llvm::sys::ExecuteNoWait (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> Program, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> &gt; Args, std::optional&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> &gt; &gt; Env, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; std::optional&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> &gt; &gt; Redirects=&#123;&#125;, unsigned MemoryLimit=0, std::string &#42; ErrMsg=nullptr, bool &#42; ExecutionFailed=nullptr, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/bitvector">BitVector</a> &#42; AffinityMask=nullptr, bool DetachProcess=false)</>}>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
The <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/sys/processinfo">ProcessInfo</a> of the newly launched process.
</SectionUser>


:::info
On Microsoft Windows systems, users will need to either call <a href="#a7defb51d8d6a2eba7a428d1a22f08bad">Wait</a> until the process has finished executing or win32&#39;s CloseHandle API on ProcessInfo.ProcessHandle to avoid memory leaks.
:::

### findProgramByName() {#ae87ab32d0995f94193aff5e380c8d251}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>ErrorOr&lt; std::string &gt; llvm::sys::findProgramByName (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> Name, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> &gt; Paths=&#123;&#125;)</>}>
Find the first executable file <code>Name</code> in <code>Paths</code>.

This does not perform hashing as a shell would but instead stats each PATH entry individually so should generally be avoided. Core LLVM library functions and options should instead require fully specified paths.


<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="Name">name of the executable to find. If it contains any system slashes, it will be returned as is.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="Paths">optional list of paths to search for <code>Name</code>. If empty it will use the system PATH environment instead.</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
The fully qualified path to the first <code>Name</code> in <code>Paths</code> if it exists. <code>Name</code> if <code>Name</code> has slashes in it. Otherwise an error.
</SectionUser>

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/program-h/#l00079">79</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/program-h">Program.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

getHostCPUFeatures - Get the LLVM names for the host CPU features.

The particular format of the names are target dependent, and suitable for passing as -mattr to the target which matches the host.


<SectionUser title="Returns">

### SetInfoSignalFunction() {#aae32f3b9e37b0c3f107abb91220894d4}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void llvm::sys::SetInfoSignalFunction (void(&#42;)() Handler)</>}>
Registers a function to be called when an &quot;info&quot; signal is delivered to the process.

On POSIX systems, this will be SIGUSR1; on systems that have it, SIGINFO will also be used (typically ctrl-t).

Note that signal handlers are not allowed to call any non-reentrant functions. An null function pointer disables the current installed function. Note also that the handler may be executed on a different thread on some platforms.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/signals-h/#l00089">89</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/signals-h">Signals.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### SetInterruptFunction() {#a03a7c4c80c31a619c5e452314166401a}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void llvm::sys::SetInterruptFunction (void(&#42;)() IF)</>}>
This function registers a function to be called when the user &quot;interrupts&quot; the program (typically by pressing ctrl-c).

When the user interrupts the program, the specified interrupt function is called instead of the program being killed, and the interrupt function automatically disabled.

Note that interrupt functions are not allowed to call any non-reentrant functions. An null interrupt function pointer disables the current installed function. Note also that the handler may be executed on a different thread on some platforms.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/signals-h/#l00077">77</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/signals-h">Signals.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### SetOneShotPipeSignalFunction() {#a667819e7b48d7d4f3cf99c2709aac92e}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void llvm::sys::SetOneShotPipeSignalFunction (void(&#42;)() Handler)</>}>
Registers a function to be called in a &quot;one-shot&quot; manner when a pipe signal is delivered to the process (i.e., on a failed write to a pipe).

After the pipe signal is handled once, the handler is unregistered.

The LLVM signal handling code will not install any handler for the pipe signal unless one is provided with this API (see <a href="#a916621b9926263f33c49d2dff9883db5">DefaultOneShotPipeSignalHandler</a>). This handler must be provided before any other LLVM signal handlers are installed: the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/initllvm">InitLLVM</a> constructor has a flag that can simplify this setup.

Note that the handler is not allowed to call any non-reentrant functions. A null handler pointer disables the current installed function. Note also that the handler may be executed on a different thread on some platforms.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/signals-h/#l00105">105</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/signals-h">Signals.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### writeFileWithEncoding() {#ae1fa64c0bf9c723c5960fdd815df37df}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>std::error&#95;code llvm::sys::writeFileWithEncoding (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> FileName, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> Contents, <a href="#aad87650fa22966074a3b341d0e5cef6c">WindowsEncodingMethod</a> Encoding=<a href="#aad87650fa22966074a3b341d0e5cef6caf0fd365beea6ebcbd1e26eb24015da53">WEM&#95;UTF8</a>)</>}>
Saves the UTF8-encoded <code>contents</code> string into the file <code>FileName</code> using a specific encoding.

This write file function adds the possibility to choose which encoding to use when writing a text file. On Windows, this is important when writing files with internationalization support with an encoding that is different from the one used in LLVM (UTF-8). We use this when writing response files, since GCC tools on MinGW only understand legacy code pages, and VisualStudio tools only understand UTF-16. For UNIX, using different encodings is silently ignored, since all tools work well with UTF-8. This function assumes that you only use UTF-8 <em>text</em> data and will convert it to your desired encoding before writing to the file.

FIXME: We use EM&#95;CurrentCodePage to write response files for GNU tools in a MinGW/MinGW-w64 environment, which has serious flaws but currently is our best shot to make gcc/ld understand international characters. This should be changed as soon as binutils fix this to support <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a17701f48ffa18ce5f16797db84617db2">UTF16</a> on mingw.


<SectionUser title="Returns">
non-zero error&#95;code if failed
</SectionUser>

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/program-h/#l00201">201</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/program-h">Program.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>
